urn:contentItem:6B60-TFP1-F0J6-J458-00000-00Please, take care2024-01-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Please, take careBen Fraser

Authorities asks for common sense this weekend

With thousands of Victorians expected to make the most of the Australia Day long weekend, authorities are asking the community to play it safe.

As the Grampians population swells across the three days, Victoria Police and Forest Fire Management Victoria have warned travellers and revellers.

Grampians Deputy Chief Fire Officer Jason Hellyer said common sense should be on the menu.

"Whether you're camping, walking, riding or driving, weekends are a great opportunity to discover beautiful parks, forests and reserves," he said. "We want people to enjoy forests, but with seven unattended campfires found across the Grampians region in the last two weeks, FFMVic are reminding visitors to follow campfire safety rules to make sure the bush is healthy and safe for everyone to enjoy."

Victoria is not imposing double demerit points this weekend.

urn:contentItem:69PB-NR51-F0J6-J2JT-00000-00Firefighters contain 250-hectare harvest fire2023-11-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Firefighters contain 250-hectare harvest fireJonathon Magrath

About 250 hectares of canola crop and grazing land has been destroyed in a grass fire on Tuesday, November 21.

About 100 firefighters battled the harvest fire, which sparked near the Wimmera Highway and Dunolly-Rheola Road about 3.25pm Tuesday, and the fire was marked under control just after 5pm.

A total of 25 CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria tankers arrived from far and wide at the scene, assisted by a strike squad from Bendigo.

Four aircraft were utilised to put out the blaze.

A CFA spokesperson said while no property had been damaged, some livestock had been killed.

The spokesperson said investigators were still determining the exact cause of the fire, however, the Bendigo Advertiser understands farming equipment may have been involved.

urn:contentItem:69X3-WNV1-JD34-V2VS-00000-00Bushfire reignites fears2023-12-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Bushfire reignites fearsJonathan Hawes

A massive bushfire raging through the Pilliga has sparked concern among residents about the danger of building gas wells in a fire-prone area.

The Duck Creek Pilliga Forest fire escaped containment last weekend, nearly quadrupling in size and jumping from the Pilliga into Bibblewindi State Forest.

Santos finished building two new coal seam gas wells in Bibblewindi just last month.

The oil and gas company told the Leader no equipment has been damaged so far and a full inspection would be undertaken "when it is safe to do so".

"Santos is in regular contact and working closely with the Forestry Corporation and the Rural Fire Service (RFS), including providing access to our bore water tanks in the forests to support fire fighting efforts," a Santos spokesperson said. "As a precaution Santos has proactively isolated all wells which are in the region currently impacted by the fires and continues to remotely monitor our infrastructure."

But the intensity of the fire - which is so large it created its own thunderstorm - has renewed calls to shut down the entire Narrabri Gas Project. Warrumbungle Shire councillor Kodi Brady has voiced his concerns.

urn:contentItem:69WP-H6X1-JC0X-K1K1-00000-00NSW:Narrabri bushfire prompts evacuation centre set-up2023-12-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSNSW:Narrabri bushfire prompts evacuation centre set-upSYDNEY Dec 18

  An evacuation centre has been set up at Narrabri in the state's northwest after an uncontained bushfire threatened properties in the area on Monday.


   The out of control fire in the Pilliga Forest, close to Narrabri and the town of Boggabri, has so far burnt more than 64,700 hectares, NSW Rural Fire Service (RFS) said on its website.
   The blaze was at emergency level early Monday before being downgraded to watch and act level later in the morning,
   "An evacuation centre for residents who have been affected by the Duck Creek Pilliga Forest Fire has been established," RFS said on Facebook.
   While the immediate threat had eased, north westerly winds were forecast to increase, which would shift the fire east, it said.
   "Landholders in the areas of Baan Baa, Wynella, and Willala should monitor the situation closely and review their bush fire survival plan and prepare their properties," the agency said.
   "Firefighters remain in the area working with property owners."
   More than 50 bush and grass fires were burning statewide on Monday, according to the RFS website, as a severe heatwave warning remained for the Northern Rivers, Mid North Coast and Northern Tablelands Districts.

urn:contentItem:69GK-FVS1-JD34-V09Y-00000-00CFA fire warning2023-10-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1CFA fire warningJohn Hall

Authorities prepare for hot summer ahead

As temperatures are predicted to soar, fire restrictions have been announced for the Northern Grampians Shire, effective November 6.

The current El Nino and Indian Ocean Dipole weather patterns covering Australia means Victorians can expect a hotter and drier summer with an earlier arrival of high-risk bushfire weather and a prolonged fire season than in recent years.

With the heightened fire threat, the CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria urged communities to prepare their properties and create a Bushfire Survival Plan.

CFA District 16 Assistant Chief Fire Officer Bernie Fradd said while local grass loads are still relatively green and benign, it only takes a few warm days for grass to dry off enough to become a fire hazard.

"With September and October having historically low rainfall it is important that people take care while clearing up around their property," ACFO Fradd said.

urn:contentItem:69PG-D7H1-DY66-549T-00000-00Massive area scorched in out-of-control burn-off near Ballarat2023-10-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisMassive area scorched in out-of-control burn-off near Ballarat

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Timothy Cox

About 40ha of land were scorched in a fire southwest of Ballarat that burnt overnight and into Thursday morning.

The CFA was called to an out-of-control private burn-off on Donald McLeans Road, Berringa at 4.42pm on Wednesday.

Some seventeen vehicles, as well as strike teams and Forest Fire Management Victoria, were called to help set up a containment line and restrain the blaze, which was heading south.

The fire was contained at 7.35am on Thursday and a previously-issued Watch and Act was downgraded to an Advice message, which indicated that smoke may remain visible from nearby roads.

While there is currently no active fire, firefighting crews remain on scene.

A CFA spokeswoman said weather conditions were favourable on Thursday with rain falling over the fireground and low wind speeds expected throughout the day.

Forest Fire Management is looking for people across north central Victoria who are keen to work outdoors, learn new skills, and help protect the community and environment.

Applications are now open for project firefighter roles across Bendigo, Castlemaine, Heathcote, Inglewood and St Arnaud.

"These are very rewarding roles, where no two days are ever the same," FFMVic acting deputy chief fire officer Paul Bates said.

Entries close on 30 July. To apply, visit jobs.careers.vic.gov.au/pff

urn:contentItem:69GJ-1RB1-JD2P-C1X6-00000-00The tough got going2023-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisThe tough got goingMark Collins,Corryong Courier

Year 9/10 Media Class, Corryong Courier

On Tuesday Corryong College held its annual Tough Mudder and Colour Run. This was the first time the event had been held for four years due to disruptions like Covid-19.

Paige Heinjus shows the way! Photo courtesy Corryong Courier.

The course was designed by Claudia McKimmie’s Year 9/10 fun and fitness class and had more than ten different stations including the water slide, the ice bath, silage bails, hay bale climb, mazes, hill climb and barbed-wire crawl.

The class also ran the event throughout the day.

Jesse Pitman shows flair in the mud slide. Photo courtesy Corryong Courier.

A special thank you goes to Forest Fire Management Victoria which hosed down the bank to make it slippery and even more challenging for students. The water slide was a crowd favourite and Riley Bloom said "the water slide was awesome". Paige Heinjus said "the best part about the day was being able to get mud all over you and not get in trouble".

There was also a sausage sizzle and Edward Miranda mentioned "I got a sausage for free, you just wait until they become free!"

urn:contentItem:68R8-FTW1-JD34-V2X8-00000-00Call to help fight blazes2023-07-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Call to help fight blazes

Nowra's Damien Dubrowin is answering the call to battle unprecedented wildfires in Canada.

The NSW Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS) firefighter is among 15 from the service, who will deploy this week to assist in the massive emergency.

Since May, firefighters from all over the world have assisted Canadian emergency services in battling blazes across almost every province.

A totral 880 wildfires were actively burning across Canada last, according to the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre.

Mr Dubrowin is part of the fourth deployment of NPWS specialist firefighters and the group left on Saturday (July 15) for a four-week stint.

The firefighter said the NPWS team is ready to get their boots on the ground, and offer some relief to exhausted Canadian firefighters in their time of need.

urn:contentItem:68MP-WW81-F0J6-J3S6-00000-00p1 psill2023-07-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7p1 psill

Illegal firewood collection in authorities sight From FRONT PAGE Equipment such as chainsaws and trailers can also be seized. Threatened native species, including the Powerful Owl, Greater Glider, and Brush-tailed Phascogale, rely on the trees and hollows in state forests and parks for habitat and illegal tree felling risks their survival.

The Regulator is targeting the illegal take of firewood through Operation Hollows, a joint state-wide operation with Forest Fire Management Victoria and Parks Victoria, that utilises regular patrols across public land, and intelligence-gathering methods such as concealed cameras and community reports.

The Regulator is aware that timber taken illegally from these areas could be sold on to the community. The public is asked to be vigilant when purchasing firewood to avoid inadvertently supporting this illegal trade, by asking where the wood comes from, requesting a receipt and questioning if the wood seems too cheap.

For more information, visit: https://www.ffm.vic.gov.au.

urn:contentItem:68B0-37D1-F0J6-J05Y-00000-00Pet owners wary of fox baiting2023-05-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 6Pet owners wary of fox baiting

Fox baiting in forest FOXES will soon be baited in the Wellsford forest as land managers crack down on the pest.

They will bury baits containing 1080 poison in stations throughout the area from Monday through to July 21. Domestic animals could be endangered, Forest Fire Management Victoria senior forest manager Lynda Mabon said.

"We ask that nearby landholders ensure their dogs and other pets are confined to their property," she said.

"Visitors to Wellsford State Forest are advised to muzzle their pets and keep them on a lead. Neighbouring landowners have been notified of the program and signs have been placed at entrances to the control areas so that visitors are aware of the baiting."

Fire crews will keep on patrolling a 90 hectare fuel reduction burn at Winton North - Winton North Road, seven kilometres west of Glenrowan today.

urn:contentItem:61RY-GH01-JD34-V32M-00000-00Pine forest fire near Bombala2021-01-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisPine forest fire near BombalaDenise Dion

A fire in a private pine forest on Platts Road, Mila, near Bombala, continues to burn under north west winds, the RFS (Rural Fire Service) has said.

"Crews are working to control a bush fire burning near Platts Rd, Mila approximately 10km south of Bombala. The fire is moving in a south easterly direction under north west winds," the RFS said.

"There is currently no immediate threat to property."

A spokesman for the RFS said that crews were working with NPWS crews and also being assisted by aircraft including a large air tanker which has been used to drop fire retardant on the fire.

The RFS has said the cause of the fire is not known at this stage. However local sources said there was a lot of lightning yesterday evening in the area.

urn:contentItem:61RY-GH01-JD34-V4H9-00000-00Quick action stops forest fire2021-01-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisQuick action stops forest fireKimberley Price

A grassfire near Framlingham was contained around 3.50pm on Wednesday.

Warrnambool incident controller Richard Bourke praised the quick responses from crews as an important factor in saving culturally-significant Indigenous sites.

"The crews did a great job working in a culturally-sensitive site and to protect the area," he said. "The quick response and the weather certainly helped."

The grassfire began around 12pm and 10 vehicles responded including two fixed-winged bombers and a helicopter.

Mr Bourke said the fire spread to multiple locations across the Framlingham Forest with the largest blaze spreading to around five hectares.

He said fire crews worked through the afternoon and into Wednesday evening to ensure the area was safe.

VicEmergency issued advice to Framlingham at 1.55pm to keep the roads clear for emergency services. A warning was also sent that smoke may have been visible from nearby areas.

urn:contentItem:67Y3-JW01-JD34-V3MK-00000-00Safety reminder for burns2023-04-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Safety reminder for burnsRachel Simmonds

Fire authorities have warned Victorians to take care with statewide public and private burns during current conditions.

Country Fire Authority chief officer Jason Heffernan said private burn-offs needed to be done safely with proper resources.

"While the Fire Danger Period has ended in some areas, it is still important that residents check the local conditions are safe and appropriate for burning off - both on the day and the days following," he said.

People should leave a three-metre fire break, check for ideal conditions, notify neighbouring properties and have sufficient equipment and water to prevent fires spreading.

People are urged to check the Environment Protection Authority AirWatch website for air quality updates and the Forest Fire Management Authority Victoria website for planned burn information.

urn:contentItem:67FN-7NJ1-F0J6-J2B1-00000-00Crews mop up after 13ha blaze2023-02-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Crews mop up after 13ha blazeJenny Denton

Twenty CFA appliances remained on scene blacking out and hosing down hotspots three hours after a Woodstock West grass and scrub fire broke out on Tuesday. The fire, at the corner of Woodstock and Junor roads, which was reported just after 4.40pm, burnt 13 hectares before it was stopped. The CFA said the blaze had been started by farm machinery.

Two helicopters were deployed to drop loads of water on the flames.

Forest Fire Management Victoria personnel also attended to assist.

urn:contentItem:67XW-KP61-F0J6-J16R-00000-00Easter advice2023-04-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Easter adviceBen Fraser

Fire authorities say there's no excuse for unsafe campfires

As families pack cars, caravans and trailers for a well-earned break in the Grampians' and Wimmera's iconic forests, parks and reserves this Easter long weekend, authorities urged them to obey all campfire and littering rules.

Conservation Regulator, Forest Fire Management and Parks Victoria authorised officers will visit public campsites to remind people of the rules and hand out fines for unsafe campfires and littering.

The bushfire risk remains, as many of our parks and forests are dry and full of bushfire fuel, such as dry leaves, twigs and branches.

Even with cooler weather approaching, campers must learn and follow all campfire rules, including checking weather conditions.

CFA Chief Officer, Jason Heffernan, said campers could build and maintain safe campfires by considering where and how to build a campfire.

urn:contentItem:67YY-FN61-JD34-V23B-00000-00Apsley is home to rare frog2023-04-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Apsley is home to rare frog

Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) staff from Edenhope recently made the exciting discovery of a threatened species while carrying out routine slashing works near Apsley.

Hundreds of Growling Grass Frogs (Litoria raniformis) were discovered by the crew when they noticed movement in the grass and immediately halted works to investigate further.

Growling Grass Frogs are a threatened species that are listed as vulnerable under both the Victorian Flora and Fauna Guarantee Act and Commonwealth Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act.

The discovery near Apsley is a new location for the species, with the most recent record of the Growling Grass Frog identified 14km away in 2013.

"Due to the suitable weather conditions, there may be more of these frogs out there waiting to be discovered so we ask everyone to please keep an eye out for them," she said.

All slashing works have been paused while the species is active.

If you find frogs, please do not touch or handle them.

urn:contentItem:67JV-TH41-JD34-V4KB-00000-00UPDATE: Armstrong blaze burned through 17 hectares of land2023-02-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3UPDATE: Armstrong blaze burned through 17 hectares of landVincent Dwyer

Armstrong blaze burned through 17 hectares of land A large grass and scrub burnt more than 17 hectatres of land in Armstrong between Ararat and Great Western on February 9. Multiple CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) crews called to contain the blaze.

Several crews, including 30 fire trucks and 100 firefighters, were called to the grass and scrub fire on the Western Highway around 1:30pm. The scene was declared under control at 5:26 pm.

Ground crews were supported by waterbombing aircraft and other heavy equipment, as well as a water tanker provided by the Ararat Rural City Council.

No property losses were recorded. The cause of the flame has not yet been determined.

Ground crews were supported by waterbombing aircraft and other heavy equipment, as well as a water tanker provided by the Ararat Rural City Council.

No property losses were recorded. The cause of the flame has not yet been determined.

A large grass and scrub fire is currently burning in Armstrong between Ararat and Great Western, with multiple CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) crews called to contain the blaze.

Several crews, including 30 fire trucks and 100 firefighters, were called to the grass and scrub fire on the Western Highway around 1:30pm.

Ground crews are currently being supported by waterbombing aircraft and other heavy equipment, as well as a water tanker provided by the Ararat Rural City Council.

urn:contentItem:67FF-8M11-F0J6-J1XH-00000-00Firefighters mop up 13 hectare grass and scrub fire at Woodstock West2023-02-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisFirefighters mop up 13 hectare grass and scrub fire at Woodstock WestJenny Denton

Twenty CFA appliances remained on scene blacking out and hosing down hotspots three hours after a Woodstock West grass and scrub fire broke out on Tuesday evening.

The fire, at the corner of Woodstock and Junor roads, which was reported just after 4.40pm, burnt 13 hectares before it was stopped.

The CFA said the blaze, which didn't threaten any structures, had been started by farm machinery.

Units from Inglewood, Maldon, Lockwood, Dunolly, Marong, Baringhup West, Woodford West, Tarnagulla, Newbridge, Maiden Gully and Kangaroo Flat turned out to tackle it.

urn:contentItem:5XWY-V7N1-F0JP-W46S-00000-00BUSHFIRE CRISIS SA ABLAZE AGAIN Bombers, strike teams battle Kersbrook forest fire2020-01-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5BUSHFIRE CRISIS SA ABLAZE AGAIN Bombers, strike teams battle Kersbrook forest fireMITCH MOTT

A FIRE sparked by a falling tree in the Adelaide Hills was last night threatening to spread to the north, south and east as a cool change swept across the state.

The Country Fire Service declared an emergency warning for the Kersbrook fire, saying it was an immediate threat to lives and homes in the area.

The fire broke out around 7.30pm on Watts Gully Rd during a day of extreme bushfire conditions.

The CFS initially said the forest fire was burning in a south-easterly direction towards Cromer and Forreston.

The warning was later expanded to include Mount Crawford, Mount Pleasant, Birdwood and Springton.

Waterbomber aircraft responded quickly to the blaze, dropping 21 loads in just over an hour, buying valuable time as CFS units from the surrounding district rushed to the scene.

Strike teams were called to the area to combat the expanding fire zone. Further crews were scheduled for an early morning start to relieve the fatigued crews operating in the fire ground. At 8.45pm, the water bombers were called off the fire because of failing light.The Kersbrook fire was burning only kilometres from where the Cudlee Creek fire begun on December 20.

Aircraft were also called in to assist ground crews, particularly with temperatures approaching 33 degrees at the time. Firies were able to round up and contain the blaze by 2:37 pm, after which crews began mopping up the scene.

Man critical after lawnmower accident A man in his 60s is fighting for life after a medical episode on a ride-on-lawnmower which ended up in a dam. Avoca Police said the incident happened on the outskirts of the town at 10.30am Monday. Officers said it appeared the man lost consciousness while on the mower which then went on to enter the water. Police said he came off the side of the machinery, was found by a family member then flown to Royal Melbourne Hospital in a critical condition.

urn:contentItem:6795-VT41-JD34-V2SG-00000-00Firies called to Crowlands blaze2023-01-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisFiries called to Crowlands blazeVincent Dwyer

The days of La Nina and the unseasonably cool weather and regular drenchings seem to be over, as multiple CFA units were called to a grassfire in Crowlands last weekend.

Five CFA units from Ararat, Elmhurst, Crowlands and Warrak attended the scene around 2:10pm on Sunday, January 8 where it was reported a grassfire was beginning to spread.

Aircraft were also called in to assist ground crews, particularly with temperatures approaching 33 degrees at the time.

Firies were able to round up and contain the blaze by 2:37 pm, after which crews began mopping up the scene.

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews also attended the scene to fell four trees which had been affected by the blaze, after which the scene was finally declared safe around 8pm.

The incident was one of the first blazes of the season, following three consecutive years of La Nina conditions which brought unseasonably cool weather and heavy rainfall.

The latest Bureau of Meteorology climate models suggest temperatures will return to neutral by February, with the possibility of dryer conditions to return with El Nino by June.

urn:contentItem:673M-M5D1-JD34-V0V8-00000-00Firefighting choppers ready2022-12-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 8Firefighting choppers readyAlex Gretgrix

Two firefighting helicopters have arrived in Bendigo to help protect communities and the environment from bushfires this summer.

The helicopters will be used throughout the bushfire season by Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) and Country Fire Authority (CFA) to respond to fires across central Victoria.

FFMVic Fire and Emergency Preparedness regional manager Carsten Nannestad said choppers had been based in Bendigo for several years now and were a valuable firefighting asset.

"On days of elevated fire danger, as soon as the call goes out for FFMVic or CFA to respond to a fire, the water-bombing helicopter will be deployed so we can hit the fire hard and fast in the initial stages and stop it spreading," Mr Nannestad said.

"They often arrive at a fire before ground crews, providing an immediate response so firefighters on the ground have a greater chance of limiting the size and spread of fires."

The aircraft based in Bendigo are part of Victoria's fleet of 50 firefighting aircraft.

urn:contentItem:65K3-SMT1-F0JP-W0GX-00000-00Koalas killed in burn-off2022-05-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Koalas killed in burn-off

AN investigation has begun into how four koalas were killed during a planned burning operation in southwest Victoria last week.

At least two koalas were burnt alive after Mt Richmond National Park was burnt in a fuel-reduction operation near Portland. Along with the dead female and young males, two other koalas were found nearby with severe injuries and had to be put down.

It is believed the 317ha fire was lit by Forest Fire Management Victoria to reduce the fuel hazard. The koalas were found by a walker.

urn:contentItem:654D-5G01-JD34-V50C-00000-00Fox baits to be set in forest2022-04-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 2Fox baits to be set in forestDavid Chapman

An Autumn fox baiting program will begin in Wellsford State Forest on Monday, April 4 to help protect native animals and livestock from the declared pest.

Forest Fire Management Victoria (FFMVic) will lay baits in Wellsford State Forest starting next week, to reduce the number of foxes in the area, which prey on nearby livestock as well as native species.

FFMVic Senior Forest Manager and Roading Officer, Lynda Mabon said the baiting program will run until May 13.

urn:contentItem:65T5-S881-JD34-V2BN-00000-00Firewood collection season nears end2022-06-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Firewood collection season nears end

Residents will not be able to collect firewood from designated collection areas from 11.59pm on Thursday when the autumn firewood collection season ends.

Forest Fire Management Victoria team leader Amy Groch said firewood collection areas would reopen on Thursday, September 1, and restrictions to prioritise firewood for local communities in central Victoria would continue during future collection seasons.

People who collect firewood outside designated firewood collection areas or a firewood collection season or take more than what's allowed face fines of $727 or a maximum penalty of one year imprisonment or a fine of up to $9087 - or both, if the matter proceeded to court.

Financial help is available for people on low incomes who purchase firewood or wish to transition to other energy sources online at www.ffm.vic.gov.au/firewood/energy-concession-and-support

urn:contentItem:65X8-HFT1-JD3N-542F-00000-00Search for crew to 'hold a hose, mate'2022-07-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Search for crew to 'hold a hose, mate'MITCH CLARKE

THE Victorian government is on the hunt to recruit 300 forest firefighters ahead of the upcoming fire season.

The fixed-term positions are based across regional Victoria and include a number of seasonal roles, including general firefighters, fire support officers and rappel crews. Successful recruits will undertake emergency response activities, planned burning, pest and weed control, road maintenance and other land management activities.

The new crews, which will work alongside the CFA and FRV, will add to the state's existing firefighting capacity.

"You could be operating heavy machinery one week and responding to an emergency the next - no two days are the same," Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said.

Environment and Climate Action Minister Lily D'Ambrosio said the program is a "great opportunity". "If you are keen to work outdoors, want to be part of a diverse and inclusive team that helps protect our communities and environment, then I encourage you to apply," she said.

urn:contentItem:65RC-PB71-DYG0-90WJ-00000-00VIC:NSW man charged with stealing Vic firewood2022-06-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:51:30ZLexisNexisVIC:NSW man charged with stealing Vic firewoodMELBOURNE June 20

  A NSW man potentially faces a year in jail and fine of nearly $10,000 after he was busted allegedly collecting firewood in Victoria.


   The unnamed man was charged by Conservation Regulator Authorised Officers with 12 offences, including illegal firewood collecting and habitat destruction, after being observed at Lake Moodemere near Rutherglen, in the state?s northeast last year.
   In Victoria, it is a crime to remove or destroy vegetation on public land without proper authorisation.
   A joint operation between the Conservation Regulator, Forest Fire Management Victoria and Parks Victoria led officers to the man in May last year.
   He is due to appear in Wodonga Magistrates Court on July 5.
   ?The illegal removal of native vegetation is devastating for biodiversity,? Hume Conservation Regulator regional manager Greg Chant said.
   ?Habitat loss has a serious impact on iconic native species that rely on our forests to survive, such as the Powerful Owl, South-eastern Red-tailed Black Cockatoo, Greater Glider, and many others.?
